Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: @Meyse  the way i've been positioning it is as a regular backup, where we take a point in place snapshot that we can restore

Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: this is similar to a checkpoint

Author: benohanlon#1119
Content: I like a checkpoint much more than a backup

Author: benohanlon#1119
Content: as we often have to explain it's a counter

Author: benohanlon#1119
Content: i feel like a checkpoint is great because people understand you'd restart at a checkpoint

Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: how is that different than a backup restore?

Author: benohanlon#1119
Content:
a backup is something you're saving... to use it you feel like you lost

whereas a checkpoint has a more positive connotation because you're still in motion... 

maybe ive played too much mario kart?

Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: haha

Author: benohanlon#1119
Content: but you see what i mean? a checkpoint in my mind means you're in motion üòÑ

Content: i guess it depends on how you define "checkpoint"

Content: a back-up is for floppy disks

Content: 2 different audiences will interpret it differently. we can message test checkpoints

Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: but b2b will want to understand an analogy that is relevant to their businesses

Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: every company large or small understand disaster recovery and business continuity

Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: we can't really position DR, but it is a similar concept in how data protection has become a proactive design requirement, when it used to be an afterthought

Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: checkpoints do have a very specific meaning in the states, but i do get the video game metaphor

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: I mean, I like checkpoint as well, but Iron Mountain, AWS, and IBM all use "backup" for their product names and descriptions

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: which might translate better in b2b

Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: backup recovery is widely understood, but data protection is the umbrella term that has a whole set of solutions

Author: Meyse#0952
Content: for me dpow is easier explained in visuals with checkpoints, how to explain it to businesses could be better like a backup, but i dont know whats best

Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: We'll need to further message test the checkpoint concept

Content: But if someone asks "ok so what exactly is a checkpoint, and how is that actually done?"

Author: Steve Lee#1967
Content: then you'd need an analogy or simplified explanation on that

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
there's a (fairly newish but very very useful) feature of kmd assetchains to self-detect if they are on a fork and auto-rewind (using these notarization checkpoints).  this happened for the first time in the wild on may 21.
the use case encountered was during the initial sync of a chain and has been documented for some writing to be made from it.  @Steve Lee it's in the team wiki under my space with a few pages of relevant chat from notary node chatter about it.

the feature reads as though it could be extended to non-kmd-ecosystem chains in the future.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: so there's one really useful `checkpoint` example.  helps lots of nodes sync and stay in sync without the need for a team of engineers to mollycoddle a blockchain to sync across multiple nodes.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: so it lowers the barrier to entry for a dApp or organisation to enter the blockchain space without needing to be blockchain operations experts, e.g. lowers operational costs yet again by using notarization.
